recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Second Presbyterian Church was organized in 1818 due to a split (brought on by disagreements over doctrine and renting pews) in the First Presbyterian Church's congregation. They built their first church on the west side of Prince (now Market) Street in 1820. The congregation grew quickly and moved to a larger building on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Market Street in 1860. The area around the church grew more congested as Knoxville grew, and the congregation sold their Market Street property and moved to a new building on the corner of Clinch and Walnut in 1905. The congregation eventually outgrew this building as well and moved to a structure on Kingston Pike in 1957.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Named after Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, Hotel Farragut opened on the corner of Gay Street and Clinch Avenue (the site of the old Imperial Hotel) on February 1, 1919. It flourished until 1929 when the Andrew Johnson Hotel opened nearby, after which time the two hotels provided each other with stiff competition. Hotel Farragut closed in 1977 and was converted into office space in 1978.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

mods.abstract: Imperial Hotel was built on the corner of Gay Street and Clinch Avenue in about 1894. It replaced several older businesses, including Hotel Hattie. The Imperial burned down in 1916 and was replaced by the "completely fireproof" Hotel Farragut in 1919.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The original Whittle Springs Hotel was built in about 1902 about three miles to the north of Knoxville. It advertised such conveniences as electric lights, baths, unexcelled cuisine, and both telephone and telegraph connections. This structure burned in 1919, and the second Whittle Springs Hotel (shown) was constructed on the same site. This building was razed in 1964.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Four children playing in front of Jane Kennedy's home. General James White built part of the house itself (the first in Knoxville) in 1786. It was originally located at one corner of a rectangular lot with smaller houses in the other three corners, a common frontier design. After the White family established a farm away from this location, the structure was repurposed as the kitchen wing of the Kennedy residence on State Street. In 1906, Isaiah Ford purchased the building and moved it to Woodlawn Pike where he used it as a private residence. It changed hands again in 1970 when the City Association of Women's Clubs purchased the home and moved it back to central Knoxville as James White's Fort.

mods.abstract: Knoxville High School was built on the site of the old J. Y. Johnston home in 1910 and expanded in 1914 and 1920. The school's last class graduated in 1951, after which the structure served as the city schools administration's headquarters. The building was repurposed again in the 1980s to house educational programs such as adult education and continuing education.

mods.abstract: In the early 20th century, popular theory held that this building, located on Cumberland Avenue, was the first state capitol of Tennessee. There is, however, no evidence to support this claim and historians have pointed out that this structure was not built until after the capitol had moved to middle Tennessee. The building was razed in January 1927.

Pickle was a veteran of the Confederate Second Tennessee Infantry and served as Tennessee's Attorney General and Reporter of the State from 1886 to 1902.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Wonderland Park resort community (including Wonderland Hotel) was created in Elkmont in 1912 to rival the Appalachian Club's nearby resort area. Wonderland Hotel and its associated buildings became Wonderland Club in 1914 when they were sold to a group of private investors from Knoxville. Most of these private owners managed to obtain lifetime leases when the Great Smoky Mountains National Park was created. The majority of these leases were eventually converted to 20-year leases that were later extended to expire in 1992. Wonderland Hotel ceased operations when its lease expired and collapsed in 2005 while debate over what to do with the historic structures standing in Elkmont raged. Although salvage efforts were discussed, the hotel was demolished in late 2006.

mods.abstract: Businessman Edward Jackson Sanford and his wife, Emma Chavannes, bought this home from Knoxville businessman and politician James Hervey Cowan in 1890. Originally known as River Lawn, the Sanfords renamed the property Maplehurst because of the several maple trees growing on the property. Sanford died in 1902, and in 1912 his estate sold the property to Alex McMillan & Co. for development.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: View of Perez Dickinson's residence. Dickinson was born in Amherst, Massachusetts, in 1813. He moved to Knoxville in about 1830 where he quickly became a popular and successful merchant. He had this elegant home at the corner of Main and Locust Streets built in 1831. After his death in 1901, C. B. Atkin bought the house and made several additions, including a front portico in the classic colonial style. The structure was demolished in about 1950.

mods.abstract: Lamar House Hotel was built in 1817. Bijou Theatre opened as part of that hotel on March 8, 1909. Over the years, it hosted many famous vaudeville and theater acts. It ultimately fell into a period of decline, but efforts by local preservationists helped to save and restore the theater. The building was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1975.

mods.abstract: Wilbur Ellis and Harold Ernest opened Ellis and Ernest Drugstore near the University of Tennessee campus in 1926. For many years, the store served as a popular gathering place for UT students as well as Knoxville residents and tourists. The drugstore was razed in the late 1960s in order to accommodate the Carolyn P. Brown University Center, but the establishment was commemorated with the Ellis and Ernest Friendship Walk.

mods.abstract: Home of William Blount, signer of the U.S. Constitution and the Governor of the Territory of the United States South of the Ohio River, and his wife Mary, built in 1792. In addition to its impressive size, the home boasted a number of features not commonly seen on the frontier, including hardwood floors and glass windows. A group of women led by Mary Boyce Temple campaigned to preserve the home in the early 1920s, and Blount Mansion became a museum in 1925. It was declared a National Historic Landmark in 1965.

mods.abstract: In 1885, Charles McClung McGhee established Lawson McGhee Library as a memorial to his daughter, May Lawson McGhee Williams. The original building on the corner of Gay Street and Vine Avenue was replaced by this white marble structure on the corner of Market Street and Commerce Avenue in 1917. It remained in use until 1971, when a new building was constructed.

titleInfo.title: Woodside Building, Eastern State Hospital for the Insane

mods.abstract: East Tennessee Hospital for the Insane opened in 1886 with 99 patients transferred from the older Tennessee Lunatic Asylum in Nashville. In 1920, the facility's name changed to Eastern State Hospital as part of a program to rename all asylums in the state. The facility was updated in 1971 after a number of deficiencies were exposed. The hospital's name changed again, this time incorporating the phrase "Mental Health Institute," in 1977. Woodside, shown here, was added to the main complex in 1898.

mods.abstract: Captain Thomas Tomlinson built Tate Springs Hotel in the late 1800s near one of the mineral springs flowing from Clinch Mountain in Grainger County. The resort, which featured cottages, stables, a golf course, and a park, was extremely prosperous until the Great Depression. The original structure was torn down in 1936 and the property was sold to Kingswood School in 1941. The only remnant of the hotel is a gazebo standing near the mineral spring.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Charles J. McClung built Oakwood Mansion for his son, Matthew McClung, in 1870. The house changed hands in 1873 when it became home to Matthew's sister Lucy and her husband Jacob Lytton Thomas. The home was then located at the outskirts of town, allowing Thomas to farm and raise livestock. Railroad contractor Henry H. Thrasher purchased the house in about 1905 and remodeled it completely, adding porches, columns, and the brick exterior. He sold it in the late 1920s to a group of physicians who renamed it the Howard-Henderson Hospital. It was briefly known as Acuff Clinic before becoming Kingston Pike Motel in the late 1950s. When that enterprise failed, the structure was remodeled and reopened as Kingston Pike Nursing Home. It continued in this capacity until the early 1990s. It was home to a number of businesses, including a beauty parlor and a restaurant, before Sam Furrow purchased it in 1999.

In 1941, Wallace McClure Jr. donated the house to the University of Tennessee as part of the W. K. McClure Foundation for the Study of World Affairs that he had founded as a memorial for his father. The house was demolished in the 1960s.

The organization moved to this structure, standing on the corner of Commerce Avenue and State Street, in 1900. They continued to meet here until 1929 when they moved to a newer building on the corner of Locust Street and Clinch Avenue.

mods.abstract: View of the front entrance to Knoxville's old City Hall. The building was constructed in 1844 and originally housed the Tennessee School for the Deaf. It served as a makeshift hospital for both Union and Confederate troops during the Civil War but returned to its original purpose when the war ended. It became Knoxville's City Hall in 1924 and continued in this function until 1980. The structure is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: View of the Knoxville Civic Auditorium and Coliseum which opened in the fall of 1961.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: View of Perez Dickinson's residence. Dickinson was born in Amherst, Massachusetts, in 1813. He moved to Knoxville in about 1830 where he quickly became a popular and successful merchant. He had this elegant home at the corner of Main and Locust Streets built in 1831. After his death in 1901, C. B. Atkin bought the house and made several additions, including a front portico in the classic colonial style. The structure was demolished in about 1950.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Colonel James Van Deventer and his family lived in this home on Temple Avenue (later Volunteer Boulevard) from approximately 1900 until 1908. The University of Tennessee later used the structure as its Faculty Club, and the building was finally razed in the 1980s to allow for the construction of Hodges Library.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: John Craighead constructed the Craighead-Jackson House in 1818. After Robert Craighead II sold the property in 1855, the structure passed through many hands and fell into serious disrepair. In the late 1950s, the Blount Mansion Association arranged for the home's restoration. The edifice opened as a museum in 1966 and was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1973. This museum also houses William Perry "Buck" Toms' collection of 18th century silver.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Both Governor William Blount's home and office were built in 1792. Although the home, Blount Mansion, was restored and opened as a museum in the early 1920s, the office was not repaired until 1955.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: View of a two-story home in Knoxville.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Brothers Charles and George Swan founded Swan Brothers Bakery in 1883. They were originally located on Central Street and operated a stall in Knoxville's Market House. The company acquired what became their main facility on the 1800 block of Magnolia Avenue (shown) in 1928 where they continued to operate until being acquired by American Bread Company in 1989. The bakery finally closed in 1991 and the buildings were auctioned in 1992.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: East Tennessee Female Institute was founded in 1828. The academy offered such courses as arithmetic, orthography, reading, music, penmanship, astronomy, chemistry, and Latin. The institute merged with the Knoxville public school system in 1882, and this building was demolished in 1889.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: George Wesley Pickle built Pickle Mansion (sometimes called Confederate Hall and Fort Sanders Hall) at 1633 Clinch Avenue in 1889. Pickle was a veteran of the Confederate Second Tennessee Infantry and served as Tennessee's Attorney General and Reporter of the State from 1886 to 1902.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

titleInfo.title: Bradley Drug Company and Co-Operative Drug Company Inc.

mods.abstract: Bradley Drug Company was founded in 1917 and had moved to its quarters at 624 S. Gay Street in downtown Knoxville by 1920. Co-Operative Drug Company Inc. replaced it in 1925, but went out of business in under a year.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

titleInfo.title: Residence of Charles and Nellie Ross

mods.abstract: This house, which stood on Rose Avenue, was home to Charles C. Ross beginning in 1891. His sister Nellie lived with him from 1895 until she married James Milton Bailey in 1898.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Empire Building was constructed at the corner of Prince Street (later Market Street) and Church Street in 1901. Such diverse interests as labor unions, insurance agents, and lawyers rented space in this "fireproof" building.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: William D. Kuhlman opened the first of his chain of drugstores at 301 Gay Street in 1894. The store pictured, Kuhlman's Drug Store No. 2, opened at 600 S. Gay Street in 1905. It closed in 1909 but later re-opened at 607 S. Gay Street. Kuhlman eventually established three additional stores: one at 310 W. Clinch Avenue, one at 322 N. Gay Street, and one on S. Gay Street near the Tennessee River Bridge.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Richard F. Graf designed and built this house at 325 Woodlawn Pike in about 1923. The Graf family lived in this home for many years before Dr. J. P. Cullum acquired it. Graf and several of his sons operated the architecture firm R. F. Graf & Sons in downtown Knoxville from 1910 until 1942.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Central Methodist Episcopal Church South, designed by Chattanooga architect R. H. Hunt, was dedicated in March 1927. It represented a combination of two older Knoxville Methodist congregations: Broad Street and Centenary. The church was renamed Central United Methodist Church when the United Methodist Church was formed in 1968.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The University of Tennessee built the 21-story Kingston Apartments in 1968 in order to accommodate its rapidly expanding student population. The building served as married and graduate student housing until 2006 when New York developer Stanley Mohr bought the property with plans to turn it into a private apartment building.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks Home was originally located at 421 W. Main Avenue. The Elks moved to the Home pictured here in 1909 when Colonel J. Y. Johnston took over the Main Avenue property to use as his private residence. This picture is a copy of a postcard that was mailed in 1909.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Although the congregation was established in the 1790s, the original First Presbyterian Church building, called the Brick Meeting House, was not finished until 1816. This structure was replaced by the one shown here in 1855. This building was razed in 1901 in order to allow for the construction of a larger facility.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: View of the Knoxville Sentinel building. The newspaper was founded in 1886 by John Travis Hearn and eventually merged with the Knoxville News in 1926 to create the Knoxville News-Sentinel.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: John Fanz Staub designed this home at 1820 Melrose Avenue for his aunt, Emma Fanz Price Hope, in 1921. Completed in 1924, the home reflects Mrs. Hope's fondness for the cottage architecture of England's Cotswold District. The University of Tennessee purchased the home in 1980, and Staub oversaw its renovation just before his death in 1981. The university turned the building, known as Hopecote, into a guest house.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

titleInfo.title: Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church, South

mods.abstract: When the Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church South building (constructed in 1875) was destroyed by fire in 1928, the structure shown replaced it. Although the new building stood at the corner of Henley and Main Streets, the congregation chose to retain "Church Street" in its name. The church's name changed to Church Street United Methodist Church when the nationwide United Methodist Church was formed in 1968. The building was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2009.

mods.abstract: When the Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church South building (constructed in 1875) was destroyed by fire in 1928, the structure shown replaced it. Although the new building stood at the corner of Henley and Main Streets, the congregation chose to retain "Church Street" in its name. The church's name changed to Church Street United Methodist Church when the nationwide United Methodist Church was formed in 1968. The building was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2009.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

titleInfo.title: Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church, South

mods.abstract: This building is the second of the two Southern Methodist Episcopal Churches that stood on Church Street between 1836 and 1928. It was built in 1875 and burned down in 1928. After the fire, the congregation elected to build a new structure on the corner of Henley and Main Streets but to retain "Church Street" in its name. The church's name changed to Church Street United Methodist Church when the nationwide United Methodist Church was formed in 1968.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Upon Mrs. Martha C. Henson's death in 1927, she left the University of Tennessee money to be used for the betterment of the school's female students. The money was used to build a women's dormitory which opened in 1930 and was named Henson Hall in her honor. The building housed Air Cadet Training Program students from 1943 until June 1944, but returned to housing women as soon as the program ended. It became an academic building in the late 1970s.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Panoramic view of the Tennessee River showing the Cherokee Bridge. Cherokee Bridge was built in 1892, but the area to be developed around the bridge never came to fruition, leading the bridge unused, eventually falling into disrepair. It was torn down in the 1930s.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The original Whittle Springs Hotel was built in about 1902 about three miles to the north of Knoxville. It advertised such conveniences as electric lights, baths, unexcelled cuisine, and both telephone and telegraph connections. This structure burned in 1919, and the second Whittle Springs Hotel was constructed on the same site. This building was razed in 1964.

mods.abstract: Brookside Mills, a textile manufacturer, was founded in 1885. By 1902, it was Knoxville's largest employer with 1,200 employees. The mill ceased operations in 1956, and the last of its buildings was destroyed in 1997.

mods.abstract: Cherokee Textile Mills was founded in Knoxville in 1917. It produced fine cotton goods on a contract basis. The mill moved from Knoxville to Sevierville, Tennessee, in 1954 as a result of Sevierville's 1951 decision to issue revenue bonds to attract nonlocal business.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: View of Market House's meat section. Knoxville's original Market House was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union Army used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960.

During the Civil War, the Union Army used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Knoxville's original Market House was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union Army used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960. This image shows the stalls of two of Knoxville's most prominent bakers, Kern's and Swan's, as well as W.E. Bradley's vegetable stall.

mods.abstract: Imperial Hotel was built on the corner of Gay Street and Clinch Avenue in about 1894. It replaced several older businesses, including Hotel Hattie. The Imperial burned down in 1916 and was replaced by the "completely fireproof" Hotel Farragut in 1919.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Originally known as the Van Deventer building, St. James Hotel was built shortly after the "Million Dollar Fire" of 1897. During the 1920s, the hotel developed a reputation as a musical center: WNOX (earlier WNAV) was located at St. James by 1923, and the Brunswick/Vocalion label set up temporary quarters in the building in 1929. A number of artists, many of whom went on to achieve national and international recognition, made recordings here during the "St. James Sessions" of 1929-1930. The hotel was demolished in 1973.

mods.abstract: Tennessee Theatre opened to the public on October 1, 1928. It featured such luxuries as brocade draperies, crystal chandeliers, carpeted draperies, and an ornate dome. This photograph was taken during a radio exhibit featured during the theater's first month of operation.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Lamar House Hotel was built in 1817. Bijou Theatre opened as part of that hotel on March 8, 1909. Over the years, it hosted many famous vaudeville and theater acts. It ultimately fell into a period of decline, but efforts by local preservationists helped to save and restore the theater. The building was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1975.

mods.abstract: This bridge was built in 1876 in order to allow traffic on Gay Street to travel over the railroad tracks. It was replaced in 1919 when Gay Street's northern end was raised by 15 feet and a viaduct was constructed. The structure gradually fell into disrepair and was closed for demolition in November 2005. It was replaced by a concrete viaduct in late 2006.

mods.abstract: View of Island Home Farm in south Knoxville. Perez Dickinson, born in Amherst, Massachusetts, in 1813, moved to Knoxville around 1830 and quickly became a popular and successful merchant. He purchased Williams Island (located on the Tennessee River) in 1869. Here, he constructed a manor house and established Island Home Farm. He raised crops of fruits and vegetables until his death in 1901.

titleInfo.title: Ewell Farm (Spring Hill, Tennessee) NOT ONLINE

mods.abstract: View of Ewell Farm. George Campbell Brown, born to Lizinka Campbell and James Percy Brown in 1840, served in the Confederate Army during the Civil War and later operated his family's farm, called Ewell Farm, in Spring Hill, (Maury County) Tennessee. Under his management, the farm expanded into one of the region's most prosperous plantations. After his death in 1893, his son Lucius Polk Brown took over the thriving family business.

mods.abstract: Reproduction of the plan showing the original layout of the city of Knoxville, drawn in about 1791. A number of the city's earliest families are represented on this map, including Humes, Henley, Cowan, McClung, Camp, Beardin, Blount, Strong, Crozier, and Craighead. The section designated "graveyard" at the bottom left survives as the graveyard at First Presbyterian Church.

This addition stretches from Ohio Street in the north to the railroad tracks in the south and Spring Street in the east to Elm Street in the west. It borders on Temple's Addition and King's Addition.

titleInfo.title: View of the Tennessee River from the UT Agricultural Experiment Station

mods.abstract: The University of Tennessee's Agricultural Experiment Station was established in 1882 with the intention of furthering agricultural research in the state. It grew quickly, and by 1900 branch stations were being built across the state so that research could be conducted under specific local conditions. These stations continue to research numerous topics and provide important contributions to agricultural science in Tennessee and around the world.

titleInfo.title: Reinterment of Catherine Sevier NOT ONLINE

mods.abstract: In the early 1920s, the Honorable S. G. Heiskell hit upon the idea of reinterring Catherine Sevier (wife of former governor John Sevier) in Knoxville. This photograph, probably taken at the site of Sevier's original burial in Russellville, Alabama, shows the Knoxville delegation dispatched to retrieve her remains. Upon their return, Sevier lay in state at the Women's Building and was reinterred with great fanfare on July 27, 1922. Former governor John Sevier's remains had been reinterred in Knoxville in 1889.

mods.abstract: Swimmers in Chilhowee Park's lake. Visible are the extreme left side of the Liberal Arts Building (constructed for the National Conservation Exposition of 1913) and the lake's distinctive walkway. Originally known as Lake Ottossee, Chilhowee Park began to develop as a recreational area in 1890 when William G. McAdoo opened a streetcar line making the lake easily accessible from Knoxville. The area was renamed Chilhowee Park in 1900 and was the site of several expositions between 1910 and 1913.

mods.abstract: Knoxville High School's class of 1909 with their teacher, Miss Williams. Knoxville High School was built on the site of the old J. Y. Johnston home in 1910 and expanded in 1914 and 1920. The school's last class graduated in 1951, after which the structure served as the city schools administration's headquarters. The building was repurposed again in the 1980s to house educational programs such as adult education and continuing education.

titleInfo.title: First electric streetcar to Lake Ottosee

mods.abstract: Although Knoxville's streetcar system was established in 1876, electric streetcars did not arrive until 1890 when W. C. McAdoo Jr. consolidated the existing streetcar lines into the Knoxville Electric Streetcar Company. McAdoo electrified four lines in all: the Lake Ottosee Line, the Park Avenue Line, the Washington Avenue Line, and the Broadway Line. The streetcar in this image, on the Lake Ottosee Line, was the first to run on the electrified lines.

mods.abstract: Named after Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, Hotel Farragut opened on the corner of Gay Street and Clinch Avenue (the site of the old Imperial Hotel) on February 1, 1919. It flourished until 1929 when the Andrew Johnson Hotel opened nearby, after which time the two hotels provided each other with stiff competition. Hotel Farragut closed in 1977 and was converted into office space in 1978.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: The original Whittle Springs Hotel was built in about 1902 about three miles to the north of Knoxville. It advertised such conveniences as electric lights, baths, unexcelled cuisine, and both telephone and telegraph connections. This structure burned in 1919, and the second Whittle Springs Hotel (shown) was constructed on the same site. This building was razed in 1964.

titleInfo.title: Portrait, residence, and office of "Parson" Brownlow

mods.abstract: View of William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow's residence and office in Knoxville with an inset portrait of Brownlow. A controversial Methodist preacher and newspaperman, Brownlow's zest for confrontation and staunch Union loyalties convinced the Confederacy to expel him from Tennessee during the Civil War, but he returned in March 1865 when he was elected governor. During his term, Brownlow convinced the legislature to ratify the 14th Amendment, reinstating Tennessee to the Union, and he made progress toward restoring the state's economic health. He served one term in the U.S. Senate before dying in 1877.

mods.abstract: The Circle Park neighborhood was home to many of Knoxville's richest and most prominent citizens during the early part of the 20th century. The area began to decline in the 1940s, and the University of Tennessee bought most of the neighborhood in the 1950s. Between 1960 and 1968, the university razed the original structures to make way for such buildings as Andy Holt Tower and McClung Museum.

mods.abstract: Knoxville's first YMCA (Young Men's Christian Association) was organized in 1854 at Second Presbyterian Church. The organization moved to this structure, standing on the corner of Commerce Avenue and State Street, in 1900. They continued to meet here until 1929 when they moved to a newer building on the corner of Locust Street and Clinch Avenue.

mods.abstract: Second Presbyterian Church was organized in 1818 due to a split (brought on by disagreements over doctrine and renting pews) in the First Presbyterian Church's congregation. They built their first church on the west side of Prince (now Market) Street in 1820. The congregation grew quickly and moved to a larger building on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Market Street in 1860. The area around the church grew more congested as Knoxville grew, and the congregation sold their Market Street property and moved to a new building on the corner of Clinch and Walnut in 1905. The congregation eventually outgrew this building as well and moved to a structure on Kingston Pike in 1957.

mods.abstract: In the early 20th century, popular theory held that this building, located on Cumberland Avenue, was the first state capitol of Tennessee. There is, however, no evidence to support this claim and historians have pointed out that this structure was not built until after the capitol had moved to middle Tennessee. The building was razed in January 1927.

mods.abstract: Originally known as the Van Deventer building, St. James Hotel was built shortly after the "Million Dollar Fire" of 1897. During the 1920s, the hotel developed a reputation as a musical center: WNOX (earlier WNAV) was located at St. James by 1923, and the Brunswick/Vocalion label set up temporary quarters in the building in 1929. A number of artists, many of whom went on to achieve national and international recognition, made recordings here during the "St. James Sessions" of 1929-1930. The hotel was demolished in 1973.

mods.abstract: Brabson Island, site of Brabson's Ferry Plantation, sits in the French Broad River in Sevier County, Tennessee. The notation "Brabson's Ferry near Knoxville, Tenn." most likely refers to the ferry that crosses the French Broad several miles upstream of Brabson Island rather than to the plantation or to the island proper. Brabson's Ferry Plantation was added to the National Register of Historic Places on June 25, 1975.

The institute merged with the Knoxville public school system in 1882, and this building was demolished in 1889.

mods.abstract: In Robert L. Nash's original vision, Talahi was to be not just a park but an entire upper-class subdivision in west Knoxville. He acquired land adjoining the new Sequoyah Hills neighborhood in 1926 and began marketing it to potential residents in 1929. Only one lot was sold before the Great Depression which put an end to Nash's dream. After Nash's death in 1933, Sequoyah Hills effectively annexed Talahi, which developed with the rest of the area into one of the city's most prominent neighborhoods.

mods.abstract: First Methodist Episcopal Church was organized shortly after the Civil War by the Reverend J. B. Ford. Their first permanent church, dedicated in 1869, stood on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Market Street. The congregation grew quickly and moved to this structure, located on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Locust Street, in 1894. The building was designed in the Romanesque style by architect H. H. Richardson. The church moved again, this time to the Hugh Sanford property, in 1966 and became First United Methodist Church when the Methodist Church and the United Evangelical Brethren merged in 1968.

mods.abstract: Knoxville's original Public Hall, better known as Market House, was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union Army used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House (shown) was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960.

mods.abstract: General James White built this house, the first in Knoxville, in 1786. It was originally located at one corner of a rectangular lot with smaller houses in the other three corners, a common frontier design. After the White family established a farm away from this location, the structure was repurposed as the kitchen wing of the Kennedy residence on State Street. In 1906, Isaiah Ford purchased the building and moved it to Woodlawn Pike, where he used it as a private residence. It changed hands again in 1970 when the City Association of Women's Clubs purchased the home and moved it back to central Knoxville as James White's Fort.

mods.abstract: The Woman's Building was originally constructed in 1897 as the Knoxville Building at the Tennessee Centennial Exposition in Nashville. The following year, a number of Knox County's women's organizations had the building moved from Nashville to Knoxville's Main Street. Unfortunately, the structure burned in 1906.

mods.abstract: The Knoxville Banking and Trust Building was completed in 1907 on the site of the original Blount College. It was Knoxville's tallest building until 1912 when it was surpassed by the Holston. C. B. Atkin later purchased the structure which he enlarged and renamed the Burwell Building in honor of his wife, Mary Burwell. The structure became famous in 1928 when Tennessee Theatre was added as part of an addition standing at 604-606 Gay Street. It was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1982.

This image shows several of the shoals characteristic of the lower water level.

mods.abstract: Boaters on Chilhowee Park's lake prior to the 1910 Appalachian Exposition. Originally known as Lake Ottossee, Chilhowee Park began to develop as a recreational area in 1890 when William G. McAdoo opened a streetcar line making the lake easily accessible from Knoxville. The area was renamed Chilhowee Park in 1900 and was the site of several expositions between 1910 and 1913.

titleInfo.title: Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church, South

mods.abstract: When the Church Street Methodist Episcopal Church South building (constructed in 1875) was destroyed by fire in 1928, the structure shown replaced it. Although the new building stood at the corner of Henley and Main Streets, the congregation chose to retain "Church Street" in its name. The church's name changed to Church Street United Methodist Church when the nationwide United Methodist Church was formed in 1968. The building was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2009.

mods.abstract: St. John's Episcopal Church was organized in Knoxville in 1826. Its original building (on the corner of Walnut and Cumberland Streets) was razed in 1891 in order to make way for a larger structure. This building, designed by J. W. Yost, was completed in 1892. When the Diocese of East Tennessee was created in 1986, the church became St. John's Cathedral.

titleInfo.title: Grand Army of the Republic Monument

mods.abstract: The first Grand Army of the Republic monument, or Union Soldier monument, was erected in the northeast corner of Knoxville's National Cemetery in 1901. This memorial featured a column of Tennessee marble topped by a statue of a Union Army soldier and a bronze eagle with its wings spread. This monument was struck by lightning and destroyed on August 22, 1904. Its replacement, shown here, was completed on October 15, 1906. It features a miniature medieval fortress and a central column topped with a statue of a Union soldier at parade rest.

titleInfo.title: Post Office and Custom House Building

mods.abstract: Completed in 1874, Knoxville's Post Office and Custom House may have been the city's first building to be designed by a professional architect, in this case Alfred B. Mullett. The structure was enlarged in 1910 and operated until a new post office was constructed in 1934. Tennessee Valley Authority occupied the building until 1976 when it was restored and repurposed as the East Tennessee Historical Center.

mods.abstract: Lewis M. G. Baker and Charles M. Himel established this private school, located on the corner of Highland and 12th Streets, in 1889. It was dedicated to preparing boys for college, and for many years the University of Tennessee and several other schools admitted its graduates without further examination. The school's building was destroyed by fire in 1893 but was replaced by a larger structure later that year. It finally closed in 1913.

mods.abstract: First Methodist Episcopal Church was organized shortly after the Civil War by the Reverend J. B. Ford. Their first permanent church, dedicated in 1869, stood on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Market Street. The congregation grew quickly and moved to this structure, located on the corner of Clinch Avenue and Locust Street, in 1894. The building was designed in the Romanesque style by architect H. H. Richardson. The church moved again, this time to the Hugh Sanford property, in 1966 and became First United Methodist Church when the Methodist Church and the United Evangelical Brethren merged in 1968.

titleInfo.title: East Tennessee Hospital for the Insane

mods.abstract: East Tennessee Hospital for the Insane opened in 1886 with 99 patients transferred from the older Tennessee Lunatic Asylum in Nashville. In 1920, the facility's name was changed to Eastern State Hospital as part of a program to rename all of the asylums in the state. The facility was updated in 1971 after a number of deficiencies were exposed. The hospital's name was changed again, this time incorporating the phrase "Mental Health Institute," in 1977.

mods.abstract: In early 1892, W. W. Woodruff offered his lot on Deaderick Street and his help raising funds to Knoxville's First Baptist Church in order to organize a new church. The product of these efforts was Centennial Baptist Church (renamed Deaderick Avenue Baptist Church in 1905), which was dedicated on September 13, 1892. The church was destroyed by fire in 1909, but was quickly rebuilt and continued to prosper for many years.

mods.abstract: Ralph Lawson Berry founded the Ralph L. Berry Funeral Home on September 20, 1928. His son, Fred O. Berry Sr., joined him in the business in 1934, but problems among the stockholders forced both to resign in 1936. In 1937, Ralph Berry, Fred Berry, and Edward Weigel founded the Berry Funeral Home on South Gay Street. In 1948, the business expanded when the Berry Funeral Home purchased and remodeled a structure (shown here) on Chapman Highway. A number of other major expansions were made in later years, including a merger with SCI Funeral Services of Tennessee.

mods.abstract: In 1943, a group of East Tennessee Baptists conceived of building a Baptist Hospital in Knoxville to alleviate a pronounced shortage of available hospital beds in the city. East Tennessee Baptist Hospital was completed in 1948, providing space for 254 inpatients and considered one of the most modern hospitals in the South. A number of additions have been made over the years, including the Blount Professional Building, the Baptist Professional Building, a Chapel, the Baptist Medical Tower, a Heart Center, an Eye Institute, a Regional Cancer Center, and several branches.

mods.abstract: View of the drawing room inside the William Blount Mansion. This home belonged to William Blount, signer of the U.S. Constitution and the Governor of the Territory of the United States South of the Ohio River, and his wife Mary, built in 1792. In addition to its impressive size, the home boasted a number of features not commonly seen on the frontier, including hardwood floors and glass windows. A group of women led by Mary Boyce Temple campaigned to preserve the home in the early 1920s, and Blount Mansion became a museum in 1925. It was declared a National Historic Landmark in 1965.

titleInfo.title: Knoxville Traction Company Reservoir and Power House

mods.abstract: Knoxville Traction Company was chartered on March 31, 1898, and eventually operated some 60 electric streetcars on 30 miles of track. It became part of Knoxville Railway and Light Company when all transit and electric operations were consolidated in 1908. The eventual successor of this organization was Knoxville Utilities Board (KUB).

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Bluff City, located on the Holston River between Bristol and Johnson City, was originally known as Choate's (also spelled Shoate's) Ford, named for Edward Choate, one of its first white settlers. It was often used as a river crossing as it lay on several popular overland routes. The town's name was changed to Middletown in 1793 and again to Union Depot (later shortened to Union) in 1859 when the East Tennessee and Virginia Railroad came through. The town was known as Zollicoffer (for the Confederate general of that name) during the Civil War, but reverted to Union at the war's end. It was finally named Bluff City in 1887 when incorporated.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: View of William Gannaway "Parson" Brownlow's residence. A controversial Methodist preacher and newspaperman, Brownlow's zest for confrontation and staunch Union loyalties convinced the Confederacy to expel him from Tennessee during the Civil War, but he returned in March 1865 when he was elected governor. During his term, Brownlow convinced the legislature to ratify the 14th Amendment, reinstating Tennessee to the Union, and he made progress toward restoring the state's economic health. He served one term in the U.S. Senate before dying in 1877.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Charles McClung built Kingston Pike in 1792. He also commissioned the first home to be built along the pike, which he named Statesview. Over the years, other wealthy Knoxvillians built more homes along the road, including Drury P. Armstrong's Crescent Bend (1832), Robert H. Armstrong's Bleak House (1856), and J.E. Lutz's Westwood (1890). Although the pike was heavily developed during the 20th century, some portions retain their original residential character.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

titleInfo.title: East Tennessee Deaf and Dumb School

mods.abstract: Tennessee Deaf and Dumb School (whose name changed to Tennessee School for the Deaf in 1925) was established in Knoxville in 1844. The original campus was the Churchwell House, but the school soon moved to land donated by C. M. McClung near the center of town. After closing during the Civil War, the school expanded quickly during the Reconstruction Era. By 1922, the institution had outgrown its quarters and moved to what had been the Dickinson Estate in South Knoxville. As in previous years, both the campus and its programs expanded quickly.

mods.abstract: Tennessee Valley Authority built Fort Loudon Dam, the uppermost of the dams on the Tennessee River, between 1940 and 1944 in order to control floods, aid navigation, create electric power, and ensure adequate water supply. The finished dam is 125 feet high and 4,190 feet long. The lake it creates serves as a popular recreation area.

mods.abstract: General James White built this house, the first in Knoxville, in 1786. It was originally located at one corner of a rectangular lot with smaller houses in the other three corners, a common frontier design. After the White family established a farm away from this location, the structure was repurposed as the kitchen wing of the Kennedy residence on State Street. In 1906, Isaiah Ford purchased the building and moved it to Woodlawn Pike, where he used it as a private residence. It changed hands again in 1970 when the City Association of Women's Clubs purchased the home and moved it back to central Knoxville as James White's Fort.

mods.abstract: View of Knoxville's old City Hall. The building was constructed in 1844 and originally housed Tennessee School for the Deaf. It served as a makeshift hospital for both Union and Confederate troops during the Civil War but returned to its original purpose when the war ended. It became Knoxville's City Hall in 1924, and continued in this function until 1980. The structure is listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

mods.abstract: English Lutheran Church was founded in 1888 and formally incorporated in 1890. It was designed to serve those Lutherans who preferred to worship using English rather than German. The church's congregation grew quickly, and this building was constructed on the corner of Broadway and Emory Streets in 1913. Martha Henson donated most of the money for the structure in memory of her late husband, James A. Henson. The building became known as St. John's Lutheran Church and has been listed on the National Register of Historic Places since April 1985.

mods.abstract: John Sevier was born in 1745 in Virginia. He fought in the Revolutionary War (most notably at the Battle of Kings Mountain) and was later involved in the short-lived State of Franklin and the campaign for Tennessee statehood. When Sevier became Tennessee's first governor in 1796, he settled in south Knox County. Here, he constructed Marble Springs Plantation which consisted of a main building (shown) and several smaller outbuildings. Sevier died in Alabama in 1815 and reinterred on the Knox County Court House lawn in 1889. His wives, Sarah Hawkins and Catherine "Bonny Kate" Sherrill, are buried nearby.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Named after Admiral David Glasgow Farragut, Hotel Farragut opened on the corner of Gay Street and Clinch Avenue (the site of the old Imperial Hotel) on February 1, 1919. It flourished until 1929 when the Andrew Johnson Hotel opened nearby, after which time the two hotels provided each other with stiff competition. Hotel Farragut closed in 1977 and was converted into office space in 1978.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

titleInfo.title: View of Cherokee Country Club and Horseshoe Bend

mods.abstract: Cherokee Country Club's original clubhouse, constructed in 1907. The structure was demolished in 1928 to make way for a more elaborate clubhouse designed by Knoxville architects Baumann and Baumann. The Tennessee River's Horseshoe Bend (later a National Military Park commemorating the Battle of Horseshoe Bend fought there on March 27, 1814) is shown as it appears from the clubhouse.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: View of the interior of First Baptist Church. Brothers James and John Moses organized the congregation that would become First Baptist Church in 1843. The church's first permanent building stood on Gay Street and was completed in 1850. The congregation split in 1869, and the dissidents formed Second Baptist Church. First Baptist Church moved to their second home (made possible in large part by merchant and philanthropist W. W. Woodruff) in 1888. A later building, located at the corner of Walnut and Main Streets, was completed in 1924 and was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1997.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

mods.abstract: Knoxville High School was built on the site of the old J. Y. Johnston home in 1910 and expanded in 1914 and 1920. The school's last class graduated in 1951, after which the structure served as the city schools administration's headquarters. The building was repurposed again in the 1980s to house educational programs such as adult education and continuing education.

location.physicalLocation: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Created and edited in general conformance to MODS Guidelines (Version 3.5).

titleInfo.title: Post Office and Custom House Building

mods.abstract: Completed in 1874, Knoxville's Post Office and Custom House may have been the city's first building to be designed by a professional architect, in this case Alfred B. Mullett. The structure was enlarged in 1910 and operated until a new post office was constructed in 1934. Tennessee Valley Authority occupied the building until 1976 when it was restored and repurposed as the East Tennessee Historical Center.

mods.abstract: In 1885, Charles McClung McGhee established Lawson McGhee Library as a memorial to his daughter, May Lawson McGhee Williams. The original building on the corner of Gay Street and Vine Avenue was replaced by this white marble structure on the corner of Market Street and Commerce Avenue in 1917. It remained in use until 1971, when a new building was constructed.

mods.abstract: In the early 20th century, popular theory held that this building, located on Cumberland Avenue, was the first state capitol of Tennessee. There is, however, no evidence to support this claim and historians have pointed out that this structure was not built until after the capitol had moved to middle Tennessee. The building was razed in January 1927.

mods.abstract: River traffic has flowed through East Tennessee since the area was settled in the late 18th century. From 1930 to 1933, Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) made a number of improvements to the river that allowed for a significant increase in the quantity of Knoxville's river trade. TVA operated Knoxville's Public Terminal (located on Neyland Drive) from 1944 to 1952, when it was leased to private interests. In 1962, the terminal was sold and became a for-hire facility.

mods.abstract: View of a barge on Pickwick Lake. Pickwick Lake, which boasts about 490 miles of shoreline and 43,100 acres of water surface, began to fill in 1938 after the construction of Pickwick Landing Dam. Although the dam is located in Tennessee, much of the lake extends into northern Alabama where it covers a large portion of Muscle Shoals and so makes the Tennessee River much easier to navigate.

mods.abstract: Wilbur Ellis and Harold Ernest opened Ellis and Ernest Drugstore near the University of Tennessee campus in 1926. For many years, the store served as a popular gathering place for UT students as well as Knoxville residents and tourists. The drugstore was razed in the late 1960s in order to accommodate the Carolyn P. Brown University Center, but the establishment was commemorated with the Ellis and Ernest Friendship Walk.

mods.abstract: Knoxville's original Market House was built in 1816. During the Civil War, the Union Army used the Market House to store ammunition and business was conducted outside. A new Market House was built in 1897 and merchants offered a wide variety of items, including baked goods, fresh meats, and homegrown fruits and vegetables from permanent stalls and wagons parked outside. After being partially destroyed by fire, this structure was demolished to make way for the Market Street Mall in 1960.

titleInfo.title: Knoxville Sentinel Building during the World Series

mods.abstract: In the 1920s, the Knoxville Sentinel maintained a board that allowed fans to keep up with the World Series baseball game. It was manned by two boys: one (seen near the police perch) relayed news to the crowd via megaphone, and the other (seen at the bottom of the board) updated the posted score. In this 1921 event, the Giants beat the Yankees 5-3.

titleInfo.title: Knoxville Electric Company (622 South Gay Street)

mods.abstract: Knoxville Electric Light and Power Company was organized in 1888. It acquired Mutual Light & Power Company in 1898, and was itself merged into Knoxville Railway and Light Company (later known as the Tennessee Public Service Company) in 1905. Knoxville's municipal utility, Knoxville Electric Power and Water Board, was established in 1939 and later became known as Knoxville Utilities Board (KUB). This image shows one of the perches that police used to control traffic in the 1920s.

titleInfo.title: World's Fair grounds including Sunsphere, United States Pavilion, and Amphitheater

mods.abstract: Aerial view of the World's Fair grounds. Visible structures include the Sunsphere, United States Pavilion, and Amphitheater. The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982 on a 67-acre area just west of the city's center. 19 nations in addition to the United States participated in the exposition which drew over 11 million visitors. While many of the buildings constructed for the event were eventually demolished, part of the site ultimately became a public park.

The Knoxville International Energy Exposition (better known as the World's Fair) was held in Knoxville from May to October 1982 on a 67-acre area just west of the city's center. 19 nations in addition to the United States participated in the exposition which drew over 11 million visitors. While many of the buildings constructed for the event were eventually demolished, part of the site ultimately became a public park.
